Changes since last submittal 
Changes to the facility and the RMP program are reflected in this RMP resubmittal and are summarized here:
¿	The use of chlorine at the plant for the cooling water system was eliminated with the replacement of a bleach.  This eliminated what was known at the Utilities covered process at the facility as well as the facility's only toxic release scenarios. 
¿	The facility added a new tower in order to expand capability to produce Polymer Grade Propylene.  This tower reflected a significant change to the PHA but did not impact the release case scenario analysis. 
¿	A re-evaluation of atmospheric storage tank inventory has led the facility to conclude that the Tankage covered process no longer needs to be reported because the 4 storage tanks that made up this covered process do not store NFPA 4 covered chemicals nor do they contain listed flammables.  Additionally, their location outside of the plant fence line eliminates their coverage for interconnectivity and co-location.

FHR is committed to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes. FHR-PA adheres to process safety policies, guidelines, and best practices that have been developed based on company and industry experience over the years. FHR's practice is to implement the controls necessary to prevent releases of regulated substances to the environment. However, if a release does occur, trained FHR personnel will respond, to control and contain the incident.
 
Prevention Program 
FHR-PA is operating under the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program. Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees and emphasis on safety has contributed to process safety. The facility has had no RMP chemical release accidents over the last 5 years. Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases, as part of a detailed prevention program.

Introduction and Policies 

The Flint Hills Resources (FHR) Port Arthur Chemical (FHR-PA) site is located at 4241 Savannah Ave. in Port Arthur, Texas.

FHR is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. FHR's management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental, Health, and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators.

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility, and planned changes to improve safety at the plant. 

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 
FHR-PA is an olefins plant located in Port Arthur, Texas. The facility produces 1.4 billion pounds of ethylene and 700 million pounds of propylene, which are both sold into the merchant market pipeline. Ethylene and propylene are basic chemical building blocks of a variety of plastic products. 

The cyclohexane unit produces approximately 1.8 million barrels of cyclohexane a year which are shipped out by tanker from the facility.  Cyclohexane is used to produce nylon, resins and films. 

There are two covered processes at FHR-PA- the Light Olefins Unit (LOU) and Cyclohexane Unit. There are approximately 28 EPA RMP regulated substances use at FHR-PA in amounts greater than the threshold quantity.

The facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119, and regulated under EPA Risk Management Program 40 CFR Part 68 - Program Level 3 requirements.

Five-Year Accident History 
EPA requires that all incidents involving regulated chemicals that resulted in any off-site impact or significant on-site impact be reported in this document. Within the last five years (October 2013 to October 2018) there were no releases of hazardous materials that resulted in off-site impacts or significant on-site impacts (e.g. injuries, death, or property damage). 

Emergency Response Program 
The facility continues to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Port Arthur Fire Department. As appropriate, the Texas State Police, local hospitals and other coordinating agencies also continue to be involved in emergency response for the facility.

The FHR-PA Plant Manager and H&S Manager are responsible for coordinating the emergency actions, in coordination with the site's full time Emergency Response Coordinator. A written and specific Emergency Response Plan coordinated with local officials is in place for the facility. The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.
